title.$value: Learn how to build Design Systems that stay alive

subtitle.$value: A practical course for designing, maintaining, and evolving accessible and sustainable UI systems.v

title.$value: Designing a system is much more than just creating components.

p1.$value: A Design System is a shared language that brings together design, code, and people. In this course, you will learn how to create one from scratch: tokens, foundations, accessibility, and maintenance processes.

p2.$value: This is not theory. You will build a living, scalable, and measurable system, with conscious decisions and real methodologies used in product teams.

caption.$value: Build the foundation before the chaos

description.$value: In this module, you will understand how to define the intent behind the system: what problems it solves, how it is governed, and what principles underpin it. You will see how to create a solid structure that supports scalability, consistency, and frictionless collaboration.

caption.$value: The invisible layer that gives everything coherence

description.$value: Aprenderás a crear, nombrar y organizar tokens de diseño para conectar Figma y código de forma robusta. Profundizaremos en jerarquía, tipología, nomenclatura, sincronización y cómo mantenerlos sin deuda técnica. También veremos estrategias de versionado y herramientas reales de gestión.

caption.$value: Systems that don't break when they grow

description.$value: Here you will discover how to plan its evolution: how to update without losing consistency, manage adoption in large teams, and maintain control over versions. We will discuss debt tracking, ownership, and signs of when to escalate (and when not to).

caption.$value: Designing for everyone is part of the system, not an add-on.

description.$value: You will learn how to integrate accessibility from the ground up: contrast, focus states, keyboard navigation, ARIA roles, visual and auditory feedback. But also cognitive accessibility: clarity, readability, mental load reduction. It is not a checklist, it is a quality standard.

You will learn how to document in a way that people will actually use the system. Structure, tone, visual language, and tools—from Figma to doc sites. How to create examples that teach themselves and document the “why,” not just the “how.”

caption.$value: The system as a product in itself

description.$value: A good system is maintained like any other product: with metrics, a roadmap, and constant maintenance. You will learn how to organize roles, governance, and contribution processes to maintain quality, even when the team changes.
